description: Variant of cond, from Middle English conduen, condien, from Anglo-Norman conduire, from Latin condūcō (“lead, bring or draw together”), from con- (“with, together”) +‎ dūcō (“lead”). Doublet of conduce.

entries.meaning: The duty of directing a ship, usually used with the verb to have or  to take and accompanied by the article "the."
examples: The officer of the deck has the conn of the vessel; the captain took the conn when she reached the bridge.

verbs.description: conn (third-person singular simple present conns, present participle conning, simple past and past participle conned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To direct a ship; to superintend the steering of (a vessel); to watch the course of (a vessel) and direct the helmsman how to steer (especially through a channel, etc, rather than steer a compass direction).
examples: The pilot conned the ship safely into the harbor.
